question: Okay. John, that was two months ago. You thought. My car is gone, John. What do you want me to say? That it's fine? Alright, it's fine.
answer: Yah! Ronnie Coleman, Mr. Olympics two years running. Yah!

question: Sit down, honey. Eat some breakfast.
answer: I am eating. Yeah it is. It's a continental breakfast. Uh, Dad, what do you call North America?

question: Enough about that. You're not going to school without breakfast. Now eat. Both of you.
answer: I can't believe those jerks took our car, can you, Mom?

question: No, I can't.
answer: What are we going to do? You're not going to do something, right, Dad? You know what I'd do? I'd get so big and mad, I'd just go crazy and kick someone's butt. I would. I swear. When I grow up I'll be so strong no one will ever take nothing from us. Not wrestling, Dad. Body building. There's a big difference.

question: Rdshxshn. No. Rdshxshn. Rdshxshn. It's a radio station.
answer: Ydugskew.

question: Well, I don't know. Do it again. I give up. Dad!
answer: Iplglgnstheflgvthntdstscvmrcndthrpblcfw chtstndsnntnndrgdndvsblewithlbrtyndjstc rll. Pledge of allegiance.

question: Wow. That's a good one. How about you, Mom?
answer: I don't want to play. You guys always make fun of me.

question: Come on, Mom. It's fun.
answer: Okay. Dashboard. What? No good? Okay. Okay. Hold on. Antenna. See. That's why I don't play.

question: And transplantation is a high risk operation. You could lose your son on the table. You may not want to take that chance.
answer: This isn't my decision. Not long. Months. Weeks. Days.

question: Mr. Archibald...
answer: I'd do the transplant. Absolutely. The first step is to get Mike's name on an organ recipient list. Once he does, his chances are very good. Your son's an extremely rare type so there's less demand. With B-positive blood, Mike could go to the top of the list right away.

question: It's not that simple. There are other considerations before a prospective recipient is placed on the donor list, Mr. Archibald. The cost of transplant surgery is expensive. In most cases, prohibitively so. Actually, we've already checked with your carrier. There's no provision in your policy for a procedure of this magnitude. What about you, Mrs. Archibald? Do you have coverage?
answer: No. I've only been working at the market a short time. You need to be there two years before you get benefits.

question: I see that you don't own your own home. No investments, stocks, bonds. And you have a little over one thousand in savings. That may very well be, but you'll have to check with your carrier on that. In the meantime, I'm afraid we're going to have to treat you as a cash account.
answer: How much does a transplant cost?

question: Transplant surgery, doctor fees, post operative treatment and immunosuppressant drugs, you're looking at two-hundred and fifty-thousand dollars minimum. We have treated him. We continue to treat him. Now I understand how upset you are, sir. But with other options available, we are not obligated to cover a procedure this costly. If you opt for replacement surgery, that's your choice. But the hospital maintains a very strict policy with respect to cash patients. We require a down payment before the patient's name can be placed on the receiver list.
answer: What kind of down payment?

question: Thirty percent. Seventy-five thousand.
answer: Our son is upstairs dying and all you can talk about is money?

question: You know what you should do? You should try that newsguy that does all those special investigative reports. You know the one. The guy with the hair. The trouble shooter. Channel eight. What's his name? Lampley. Tuck Lampley.
answer: Tuck Lampley. Hope you don't mind if I eat while we talk. I'm up to here today, you know? Go, go, go. So, what can I do you for? Why not?

question: Lots of reasons. He don't even understand half of them.
answer: What about the hospital? Yeah, Hope Memorial. Don't they have to cover it?

question: Right, right? That's what I thought.
answer: Jesus. Bureaucracy of the medical establishment, American family caught in the middle.

question: Right. Big guy versus little guy. We were thinking you could do one of them special interest pieces, you know? Send donations, write your congressman. That kind of thing.
answer: What they've done to your son is outrageous, and I want to help. But I've got to run it by my producers. I've got bosses, just like anyone else. So, leave me your phone number, and I'll get back to you.

question: What are you doing here, Lampley? Shouldn't you be out exposing tragic miscarriages or justice or something?
answer: Yeah, well, screw you, too. There's a rumor floating around, Frank. Some guy's holding the hospital hostage. Needs an operation for his kid. Any truth to it?

question: You know more than I do.
answer: You're full of shit.

question: Hey, then we're even. I never believe a word you guys say either.
answer: This is big, isn't it, Frank? I can feel it. Come on, what do you got?

question: Zip. Nothing. Read my lips. I just got here. But I promise, as soon as I know anything, you'll be the last to know.
answer: Hey, Grimes. You're a real horse's ass. You know that?

question: Yeah, well...
answer: This guy's in for the long haul, Lieutenant. He locked down the ER, barricaded himself inside, killed the power on the elevators. We could bust down the door, but the sonofabitch might start killing everybody.

question: Any other way in?
answer: I'm working on it.

question: How many hostages?
answer: Security guard here said there could be anywhere from ten to twenty.

question: Are you in charge of security?
answer: No, sir. That'd be Wally Pitoniak. He's at home. It's his day off.

question: Not anymore it ain't. Get him down here. I need to make contact with this guy. Can you get me a secure line?
answer: Lieutenant? One of our guys is on the inside. He's got a walkie-talk. You might want to give this a shot.

question: And keep the media on a need to know basis. Until I say so, the press doesn't need to know nothing. Now who's in charge of this hospital?
answer: Rebecca Payne, sir. She's off today, too.

question: Jesus Christ. Does anyone work at this hospital?
answer: It's Saturday.

question: What's that?
answer: Lasix. It's a diuretic to help get rid of some of the fluid build-up. But it's potassium sparing, so he needs this one to supplement.

question: And those?
answer: Dopamine. For his blood pressure. Dig for his heart. Primacor.

question: Gosh, it seems like so much.
answer: Yeah, it's a lot. This is antibiotic.

question: What for?
answer: It's prophylactic. Just in case. These two, I don't really know what they're for. Pain, maybe.

question: Pain?
answer: I don't know, Mrs. Archibald. I just do what they tell me.

question: What are you up to?
answer: Never mind me. You're worthless. You know that? Some security guard. You should have zapped the bastard.

question: With what? Besides, I'm not putting my neck on the line. Not for eight-fifty an hour. What the hell are you doing?
answer: Looking out for number one.

question: You want to stay alive? Sit tight and wait for the cavalry to get here.
answer: Wake up, fat boy. The cops are coming in shooting. They don't give a shit about his kid. And as soon as he realizes that, we're history.

question: Yeah? He finds out you got a scalpel, you're the one that's history, asshole.
answer: Really? He doesn't look so bad to me.

question: Listen.
answer: No, listen to me, you stupid rent-a-cop. I'm not a slob. I've got a life, and it means something to me. I'm not dying in this shithole.

question: Nothing personal, Doc, but you all are a bunch of damn crooks.
answer: You see,here's the problem. Over here, you've got your insurance companies who basically want you healthy or dead. That's how they make money. And over here, you've got your medical establishment, doctors, pharmaceutical companies, who don't want you healthy or dead. They want you sick. That's the way they make money.

question: It's all about getting paid, man.
answer: And the individual is caught in the middle of this gigantic tug-of-war. It's a game. And the end result is, people don't get the treatment they deserve.

question: You're looking at it.
answer: Are you there, Frank?

question: Yeah, I'm here.
answer: I changed my mind. I am going to let some of the hostages go.

question: Great, John. That's the right thing.
answer: But when I do, the clock starts. You have one hour to get back to me with some good news.

question: Isn't it a little early for you to be here, Gus? Who called in the heavy artillery?
answer: I mean it, Frank. If my boy's not on the list in an hour, I promise you someone's going to die.

question: Mrs. Archibald? Could we have a word with you?
answer: This is my fault. When the hospital told me they were releasing Mikey, I was furious. I yelled at John to do something, anything. I never thought...

question: I understand. Is he a violent man, Mrs. Archibald.
answer: No. Heavens, no. He's gentle. He's sweet. He wouldn't hurt a fly.

question: That's not what he's saying. He's talking about killing people. Has he spent any time in the military?
answer: Hey, what is this? I get what's going on here. You want me to tell you something you can use to hurt my husband.

question: He's in a lot of trouble, Ma'am. We're going to need you to talk to him.
answer: Let's get something straight, Mister. You can't use me to make a case against John. I support my husband. Whatever he does. I'm on his side. Not yours.

question: Let's get something straight, Mister. You can't use me to make a case against John. I support my husband. Whatever he does. I'm on his side. Not yours.
answer: Mrs. Archibald...

question: You, don't talk to me. I'd tell you what I think of you but I'm a Christian woman. Now you people leave me alone. I have a sick child to look after.
answer: I've decided to put Mike's name on the organ recipient list, Mrs. Archibald. The hospital will pay for everything.

question: What's going on? Where is everybody?
answer: We're sending in one of ours through the ventilation ducts. If we can get the target to that phone, it's a clear shot.

question: Is that right?
answer: Yes, Lieutenant. That is right.

question: On who's orders? Gus...
answer: Not one word. I don't want to hear one goddamn word out of you, Frank.

question: I'm not going to say anything. I'm just going to go get you your red nose.
answer: What did you say to me? Are you calling me a clown? I swear to God, I'll kill you.

question: You going to do this behind my back, you sonofabitch?
answer: Check the time, Frank. Look at your watch, Frank. The guy said at a quarter after he was going to start killing everybody, and we don't have any reason not to believe him.

question: So goddamn stupid.
answer: Yeah? What's your great idea?

question: There are no great ideas!
answer: Right! Exactly. But right now I've got a shot at this guy. I don't even know what we're talking about. You know the score. You always take the clear shot.

question: The wife has agreed to speak to him. Let her talk him down.
answer: That's exactly what we're going to do.

question: What? You use the man's wife to set him up?
answer: Whatever works. Let me paint a picture for you. And I hope it's clear. What we've got is a lose/lose. If this guy starts whacking out the hostages, it's bad, right? But if we give in to this asshole, it's also bad.

question: Bad for who?
answer: It's an election year. Do you want me to spell it out for you? A, B, C. However it goes down, this guy's not going to make it.

question: So, you kill him? That's a P.R. bonanza.
answer: There's not going to be a slaughter in there. Not on my watch. You're out, Frank.

question: Out?
answer: Out. No hard feelings. But you're officially relieved of duty. I'll handle it from here.

question: You?
answer: It's not my first trip around the dance floor, you know.

question: Yeah.
answer: Hey, I don't like it any better than you do, but I'm under a lot of pressure here. Everyone is wetting their pants on this one. Believe me, my ass is swinging in the breeze.

question: What about the hostages?
answer: They better keep their heads down.

question: Julie...
answer: Leave me alone.

question: I'm sorry. I'm a lousy drunk, okay? I get out of control. I don't mean to, but I do and I lose my mind. But that doesn't mean I don't love you. And I'll change. I swear to God, I will. It's you and me, baby. All the girls in the club, they don't mean shit to me. It's only you. I'll get down on my knees if you want me to. Look, I'm on my knees in front of everyone. I'll even forget you kicked me in the nuts. Come on.
answer: No, Mitch. This is always how it goes. You treat me like shit, then come crawling back to me like Prince Charming. Not this time. It's over.

question: Aw, come on. Don't do that. That ring cost me twenty grand.
answer: Poor little rich boy. Used to getting everything he wants. Buying his way in and out of everything.

question: How long have we been doing this? You've got to trust me on this one. Gus, I like the guy.
answer: Well I don't. I don't like nut jobs who point guns at innocent people. It pisses me off.

question: He's not a nut job.
answer: Maybe you're right. Maybe he's bluffing. Maybe he's just a nice guy with a problem. Maybe he's misunderstood and needs to blow off a little steam. Hey, it's possible. But I can't depend on that, Frank. This asshole has raised the stakes real high. And I need to match it, just in case he's not bluffing. Now, we've got five minutes before he starts throwing bodies out the door. I've got a chance to end this right now and I'm taking it.

question: I'm telling you, you're making a mistake.
answer: Yeah, well. We try harder.

question: I want to be on the record. Monroe hands Grimes a set of headphones.
answer: You can be on whatever you want. Now I got you a chair. Put these on and have a seat.

question: Gus...
answer: Will you stop already? Jesus, Frank. You're so emotional.

question: How come you're not here, Dad? Where are you?
answer: Oh, I'm kind of tied up right now. I can't get away.

question: Mom says I need a new heart.
answer: That's right, champ.

question: What's wrong with my heart?
answer: Not a thing, buddy. Not a thing. We just have to put a new one in so you can be stronger, okay?

question: Alright.
answer: Alright, what?

question: Let's go out there. See what he wants.
answer: But I thought you said I was out.

question: I stepped in shit, Frank. Is that what you want to hear, goddammit? Now quit breaking my stones. I need you to save my ass on this one.
answer: Hold your fire. John.

question: This is Sergeant Moody and Police Chief Monroe.
answer: What are we doing, John?

question: I don't want you dead. Nobody wants to kill you. That wasn't my call. I --
answer: John, listen to me. Lieutenant Grimes had nothing to do with that. It was my call.

question: Dad, where have you been? I'm okay. Tired.
answer: Out. I need some time to examine Mike and I don't need you getting in the way. It's crowded enough in here. I'm serious, John. Let me do my job.

question: Are you God?
answer: Yeah, kid. Yeah, I am.

question: Where you been?
answer: John? Mike's blood pressure has dropped into the mid-forties. His atrial blood pressure should be in the low teens. It's thirty-five. If I put that LVAD into him, his heart will never be able to handle the extra strain. Not buts, John. Without a new heart, he's not going to make it. What?

question: That Mike's going to die.
answer: I know you only think of Mike as a patient, but he's a great kid. Really. He's like magic, you know? He loves bodybuilding. You believe that? And he's funny. You'd like him, Doc. You'd really like him, if you knew him.

question: I do like him. I'd like to. I really would. But what you're asking crosses the line. It's completely unethical.
answer: I don't think you understand. I'm not letting him die. Haven't you figured that out by now? I don't care what I have to do.

question: So, what, you're going to kill me if I don't operate.
answer: And we'll just see what happens.

question: Alright.
answer: Alright, what?

question: I'll do it. If that's what you want.
answer: Wait a minute. Are you serious?
